Among those things, current Jenkins focuses on the following two jobs:

1) Building/testing software projects continuously, just like CruiseControl or DamageControl.

2) Monitoring executions of externally-run jobs, such as cron jobs and procmail jobs, even those that are run on a remote machine. ";s:8:"features";s:2306:"<font size="2" color="#182e7a">Easy installation</font>
<ul>
<li>Just java -jar jenkins.war, or deploy it in a servlet container. No additional install, no database.</li>
</ul>
<font size="2" color="#182e7a">Easy configuration</font>
<ul>
<li>Jenkins can be configured entirely from its friendly web GUI with extensive on-the-fly error checks and inline help. There's no need to tweak XML manually anymore, although if you'd like to do so, you can do that, too.</li>
</ul>
<font size="2" color="#182e7a">Change set support</font>
<ul>
<li>Jenkins can generate a list of changes made into the build from Subversion/CVS. This is also done in a fairly efficient fashion, to reduce the load on the repository.</li>
</ul>
<font size="2" color="#182e7a">Permanent links</font>
<ul>
<li>Jenkins gives you clean readable URLs for most of its pages, including some permalinks like "latest build"/"latest successful build", so that they can be easily linked from elsewhere.</li>
</ul>
<font size="2" color="#182e7a">RSS/E-mail/IM Integration</font>
<ul>
<li>Monitor build results by RSS or e-mail to get real-time notifications on failures.</li>
</ul>
<font size="2" color="#182e7a">After-the-fact tagging</font>
<ul>
<li>Builds can be tagged long after builds are completed</li>
</ul>
<font size="2" color="#182e7a">JUnit/TestNG test reporting</font>
<ul>
<li>JUnit test reports can be tabulated, summarized, and displayed with history information, such as when it started breaking, etc. History trend is plotted into a graph.</li>
</ul>
<font size="2" color="#182e7a">Distributed builds</font>
<ul>
<li>Jenkins can distribute build/test loads to multiple computers. This lets you get the most out of those idle workstations sitting beneath developers' desks.</li>
</ul>
<font size="2" color="#182e7a">File fingerprinting</font>
<ul>
<li>Jenkins can keep track of which build produced which jars, and which build is using which version of jars, and so on. This works even for jars that are produced outside Jenkins, and is ideal for projects to track dependency.</li>
</ul>
<font size="2" color="#182e7a">Plugin Support</font>
<ul>
<li>Jenkins can be extended via 3rd party plugins. You can write plugins to make Jenkins support tools/processes that your team uses.</li>
</ul>";s:5:"views";s:5:"12614";s:7:"ratings";s:5:"0.000";s:5:"votes";s:1:"0";s:7:"reviews";s:1:"0";s:5:"space";s:8:"76726272";s:7:"support";s:21:"http://jenkins-ci.org";s:7:"version";s:5:"1.610";s:8:"category";s:10:"projectman";s:4:"logo";s:8:"logo.gif";s:10:"screenshot";s:14:"screenshot.jpg";s:11:"description";s:445:"Jenkins is an award-winning application that monitors executions of repeated jobs, such as building a software project or jobs run by cron.

<li>RSS enclosures for distributing files or podcasting.</li>
<li>Simple content publication workflow.</li>
</ul>
<font size="2" color="#182e7a">Reader responses</font>
<ul>
<li>Reader responses, in the form of threaded comments and MovableType TrackBacks.</li>
<li>E-mail notifications when new responses are received.</li>
<li>Pluggable moderation, spam detection and CAPTCHA support.</li>
<li>Bulk response management features to approve/reject/remove comments and TrackBacks.</li>
</ul>
<font size="2" color="#182e7a">Web-based Adminstration</font>
<ul>
<li>Management of your blog via a web browser.</li>
<li>File management and the ability to upload arbitary files and images.</li>
<li>Capture of blog referers, requests and logs for viewing or export.</li>
<li>Customizable regex based referer filters to combat referer spam.</li>
</ul>
<font size="2" color="#182e7a">Newsfeeds</font>
<ul>
<li>RSS 2.0, RDF and Atom 1.0 feeds for blog entries and responses.</li>

<li>PubSubHubBub support via plugin</li>
</ul>
<font size="2" color="#182e7a">Navigation</font>
<ul>
<li>View blog entries by permalink, day or month. * Navigate through your blog entries in several ways, including a locale-aware calendar control. * Text based and advanced searching.</li>
</ul>
<font size="2" color="#182e7a">Team, project, multi-user blogs and security</font>
<ul>
<li>Multiple people can contribute to a single blog.</li>
<li>Multiple people can contribute to a single blog.</li>
<li>Host more than a single blog for a project, group or community.</li>
<li>Integrate Pebble with your existing security infrastructure (e.g. LDAP, Active Directory, RDBMS, etc).</li>
<li>Login using any OpenID provider.</li>
</ul>
<font size="2" color="#182e7a">i18n</font>
<ul>
<li>Content in international character sets such as UTF-8.</li>
<li>Publication of content aligned with your timezone, regardless of where your host is based.</li>
<li>Locale sensitive delivery of dates, times and numbers.</li>
</ul>
<font size="2" color="#182e7a">Plugin APIs</font>
<ul>
<li>Permalink Providers let you customize the format of your permalinks.</li>
<li>Content Decorators let you customize how blog entries are displayed.</li>
<li>Blog Listeners let you write Java code that is called when your blog starts up and shuts down.</li>
<li>Blog Entry Listeners let you write Java code that is called when blog entries are added, removed, published and unpublished.</li>

Trac uses a minimalistic approach to web-based software project management. Our mission is to help developers write great software while staying out of the way. Trac should impose as little as possible on a team's established development process and policies. ";s:8:"features";s:2240:"<h2>Open source project management tool</h2>
			<p>
			Trac is a lightweight project management tool that is implemented as a web-based application, written in the Python programming language. It emphasizes ease of use and low ceremony, and is open source.
			</p>
			<p>
			Ideal for managing software developments, it is flexible enough to use for many types of projects. As it's open source, if it doesn't quite fit your needs, you can always make changes yourself, write plugins, or commission someone else to do so.
			</p>
			<h2>Ticket system</h2>
			<p>
			Track the progress of resolving individual bugs, issues, feature requests, and ideas - each with its own ticket (numbered, as in a waiting room queue system). Easily reconcile overlapping tickets (where more than one person reports the same thing). Search and filter tickets by severity, project component, version or owner (among others). 
			</p>
			<h2>View progress</h2>
			<p>
			Trac gives you a number of convenient ways to stay on top of events and changes within a project. You can set milestones, and view a roadmap of progress towards them (as well as historical achievements) in summary. There is a timeline of individual changes so you can see the order of events, starting with the most recent. Trac supports RSS for content syndication: allowing people to subscribe to those changes outside Trac itself, as well as email notification.
			</p>
			<h2>Online repository viewing</h2>
			<p>
			Trac gives a highly usable browsing and management front-end for Subversion, a modern open-source version control system. Trac gives you clear and elegant code highlighting and file comparison, so you can easily see how files differ. Using plugins, Trac also supports other version control software.
			</p>
			<h2 >User management</h2>
			<p>
			Trac has a simple permission system to control what users can and can't access. Can be enhanced with th:AccountManagerPlugin and other plugins.
			</p>
			<h2 >Wiki</h2>
			<p>
			Built-in documentation server, which can be used for developer or user resources. As it's a Wiki, it can be set up to allow shared editing. Uses MoinMoin syntax and magic links to tickets, reports and source.
			</p>";s:5:"views";s:4:"1488";s:7:"ratings";s:5:"0.000";s:5:"votes";s:1:"0";s:7:"reviews";s:1:"0";s:5:"space";s:6:"578244";s:7:"support";s:25:"http://trac.edgewall.org/";s:7:"version";s:5:"1.0.5";s:8:"category";s:10:"projectman";s:4:"logo";s:8:"logo.gif";s:10:"screenshot";s:14:"screenshot.jpg";s:11:"description";s:346:"Trac is an enhanced wiki and issue tracking system for software development projects. Trac uses a minimalistic approach to web-based software project management. Our mission is to help developers write great software while staying out of the way. Trac should impose as little as possible on a team's established development process and policies.
